comments.commentBody:
A very interesting post! Direct and provocative. But also, in my view, a bit one-sided.
 
I believe the author undermines the energy and enthusiasm, and the potential, of recent graduates / post-graduates in India.
 
For me, a very valid question is this: What is the corporate world doing to change some of these things?
 
- How many management trainee programs (and some are REALLY elaborate and expensive) have a module on effective communication (in English). From what I know, very few.
 
- Problem-solving: I don't disagree that the rote-memorization 'method' has killed the education system, but how many companies engage fresh graduates in roles / tasks that require them to solve problems? Most of them are tasked with basic admin or tedious/routine fieldwork or project coordination. If the education system fails to instil this ability, the corporate world does little to find it.
 
- Asking questions: We shouldn't undermine the fact that in their early twenties, most people are likely to be quite overwhelmed by the cold setting and the apparent hierarchies that most employers offer. Shouldn't the hiring managers make more of an effort?
 
- Job-hopping and salary negotiations are realities across job levels in organizations. When people are young, they need more guidance around what's important for them, and where they can find it. Are employers interested in working on that?
 
I like that the author addresses the matter - but I feel that blaming only the graduates is naïve.

Sad and deeply disappointed by the strongly polarized views of a KPMG partner. I am nowhere close to being a partner, but I have learned from my experience that all these five (5) points that the partner raises have steep learning curves. India is a country where education emphasizes heavily on grades. Given this, a person at the level of partner at a big 4 consulting firm should consider prevailing upon the current educational institutions to help students equip themselves with these much needed skills. This is a rather discouraging piece of article.

For the lack of better words, I want to say that this seems like an emotional outburst! India would not have been called a service giant without quality delivery from the many graduates that work at these firms.

India is at a point where leaders and experts should help with larger policy changes. Pointing out theses issues is one thing, albeit in this manner, there is something to be said about people who can identify the underlying issue and help improve it at grassroots level. Absolutely nothing comes out an outburst as such which is very discouraging.

While I appreciate Mr. Harris's reporting on the monkey's in Delhi, it is beneath the standards and ethics of the NY Times to be presenting this "solution" from a non Indian.

What is it about Westerners claiming to have all the answers for other societies? Certainly this should never be the job of the NY Times.

And under any circumstances, this "solution" by Mr. Harris is pathetic by any standards.
The Times uses English.
Please -- it's the Ganga, not the Ganges

Point #5- What nonsense! Employers, like their employees, live and operate in a free market. In other words, employers are under no obligation to hire someone and pay them a certain amount.  They do so to be competitive. Similarly, when an employee takes a competing offer to their boss, they are demonstrating their own value. Likewise with the demand for an increased salary. If you feel like they aren't worth it, then don't offer them the money and let them go elsewhere. Otherwise put up and shut up

I just remembered "Kim" which I carried with me for a few years. You might like A Norton Critical Edition, W-W Norton & Co., New York London. There is a Said commentary kind of rehabilitating Kipling.

I am stuck on the Bengali thing. See www.baularchive.com and http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ergu4C6wiEY

regarding the first point being made-"read and write english fluently"..its an agenda of british to impose their language all over the place. Many countries (esp. in Europe or see Japan) don't speak english. So do these countries not trade there? I have seen this imposition happening all over the place.
regarding the remaining points- its a bias. I have seen the quality of students at many places in world, and its the same everywhere.

Seen enough of this propaganda against indian education system (which is westernized enough). Its same as what white americans say about black americans "average IQ of blacks is 10-15% less than whites"!!

A modest proposal for abandoned Pet Dogs/Cats in USA
===========================================

Every year millions (or high number) of dogs and cats are
abandoned in USA.

My proposal is to make serving Dog meat in restaurants legal,
so some dog meat lovers can taste them.

Please do the same for cats, horses also

or maybe export dogs and cats to countries which love eating them.

Atleast those animals are not put into painful scientific "experiments"
Is this piece supposed to be a joke?

comments.userLocation: Lewis Family Farm, Essex, New York
comments.commentBody:
Modest Proposal: In 1729 - in an epic sarcasm borne of sadness - Jonathan Swift had in mind eating the children of Ireland's poorest - to address poverty and famine at the same time. His sarcasm was aimed at the wealthy and those who had feelings about Rome, among others. Swift would have had fun with America's John Birch types, not to mention our Tea Party folks. ”I have been assured by a very knowing American of my acquaintance in London, that a young healthy child well nursed is at a year old a most delicious, nourishing, and wholesome food, whether stewed, roasted, baked, or boiled ...”

Meanwhile, the Rhesus Monkey use in research actually makes good sense - and is not sarcastic. With India crawling with these offensive monsters, this makes perfect sense. Disease and danger ride in the mouth of every monkey.

This proposal is not modest. It's fabulous. American ingenuity... from The New York Times...

Agreed, except on job hopping. Both KPMG (used only as a metaphor) and the young aspirants are in an open market where switching costs for both are low. KPMG should compete to retain employees and not depend on out of place loyalties.
www.facebook.com/sreeancheri
I enjoyed reading this interview. Kudos to the interviewee and the interviewer. Tolerance and kindness to other species is one of the great accomplishments of Indian civilization.

Theres no need to cast everybody in the same mould Mr. Chandra.If we were to become americans,we would be looking at another country to do our work for us.Similar to what is happening now,Mr. Chandra.With all our big words and grammatical errors,we work in our own way,fitting in and contributing everywhere.YOU Mr. Chandra,need to respect the people that the people are.The way you are awed by the "mature" west and their "work culture",you are probably more american than the americans themselves, and hopefully you have "gotten" your mileage by writing this "brilliant insightful piece".
latter or letter (first sentence)........... I rest my case.

I agree with just about everything said in the article!  Instead of being defensive about the criticism, the smarter thing to do is to acknowledge the drawbacks and actively seek for ways to address them.  Be aware -it is a global market!  Many other countries are waiting to jump in.  Also, the author is giving valuable (and free) consulting - shouldn't you take it?  Any smart consultant would!
You're also all - with a few exceptions - just terrible swimmers. Beware the fast food plague!

Though what you've mentioned is quite true, Indian being more like Japanese than Americans by virtue, I would like to point out one of the biggest differences I've seen between working with Indians and Japanese. Its pretty simple really, indians are not hard working enough and now a days rather than working towards a common goals (for the employer) they work for themselves. I mean I've had colleagues who would try to get their way even for even the smallest of things by threatening to quit. Else they just find a way to push the work the next guy.

I believe Indians can do much better if they are ready to accept work n get things done. Making excuses and pointing out problems is now how things get done, rather finding the solutions to the problem is really the way to go.

As far as having ambition is concerned, most companies in India struggle to hold bright people, because the company lacks ambition, not the employee. Most companies in India (MNC and Indian) do not have the capability and work to enthuse the young men and women who join them.
Bolero
I don't think any hitting coach is going to help Ike. He seems so overmatched it's hard not to think he's still sick.

So wonderful to hear Mike's feelings about the '94 Eastern Conference Finals. Mike, you stood on your head for your team & Ranger fans love you for that & always will. You  played your position in net the way it should be played, not what goal tending has evolved (or devolved) into. We love you Mike and I personally would give my eye teeth to have you in goal right now!! Thank you for making it last a lifetime and believe me, it has!!

I'm a black female graduate of BMCC and I went on to graduate from a non CUNY four year school. I see nothing wrong with the changes. I'm a product of the public school system and I had to take a remedial math course. I took school seriously. I studied hard and graduated on time.

This is a good thing. One of the main reasons I opted for a private college over a CUNY for my bachelors was because of the poor reputation of the schools due to open enrollment. Who wants a degree that isn't worth the paper it's written on? When I attended BMCC most of my classmates showed up and did the work but a significant portion showed up for the financial aid checks. They were disruptive in class and usually dropped out in Nov or April after funds were dispersed.

Parenting matters. My parents were poor immigrants and our family was a bit dysfunctional. However education was pushed and disrespecting a teacher was a major punishable offense.

My children attend public school and we supplement their education by teaching them at home. Hooked on phonics is good. Use the public library. Take the kids to museums and spend a few dollars on a workbook or two. Make them speak properly. Instill respect for teachers, get involved in their school work, and don't expect the public school system to do all of the educating.

It works.

I would also ask whether many black and Hispanic students are applying to college in the first place. I suspect that it is less "they applied and didn't get in" and more "they didn't apply," which is also a failure of the public school system.
That's an excellent idea!  We can call it the "Great Society" initiative!
